bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Dorma V. Schnurr, October 21, 1940

div1.p: Hench gives Schnurr some background information for the speech he is giving at Washington and Jefferson College.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Dorma V. Schnurr, October 21, 1940
div1.opener:
October 21, 1940
Miss Schnorr
Rochester Post Bulletin
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Miss Schnorr:
div1.p:
Here is the Appe you asked for. Although the chief items of news value
(if any) are probably confined to the last 7 pages I would appreciate it greatly
if you would read over not only my abbreviated version of the first 6 pages but
also, if at all possible, the fuller version. I am so anxious that in this case
the tail will not wag the dog. In your loyalty to me as a local citizen I don't
want you to forget that the affair is the dedication of the Lazear Memorial
Chemistry Building at Washington and Jefferson College and that it is the yellow
fever martyr Lazear and not your humble servant who is being honored. Hence,
my request that you read the full account so that you can have the proper back-
ground and know why he is being honored. In his memory Washington and Jefferson
College is honoring the American medical profession by granting honorary degrees
to several American physicians. I don't know who they are except that one is to
be Dr. Wilbur A. Sawyer, Director of the Rockefeller International Foundation and
the world's leading authority on yellow fever. He is the main speaker of the
morning affair. I am the main speaker at the evening affair, but Moran and
Kissinger are the honor guests at the whole affair. (It was the part of Moran which
James Stewart took in the stage version and Robert Montgomery took in the movie
version of “Yellow Jack.” Moran was “O'Hara” and Kissinger was named Brinkerhof
in the play.) Mrs. Lazear and Dr. Cooke, were also invited but I think were unable
to go.

My contribution to all this results from the historical investigations
which I carried out this spring in Havana (and since then by voluminous
correspondence:) with Moran and Mr. Luis 3. Pogolotti (Havana engineer) which
began when I decided the Cuban government had erred in purchasing and marking
the wrong site as “Camp Lazear.” Of news value on this angle may be, t. belated
discovery of the extent of Dr. Lazear's martyrdom. He died of experimental, not
accidental yellow fever, 2. discovery that the site marked by the Cuban government
was not the site of Camp Lazear but the site of the yellow fever tent hospital
where Lazear died, (Hence their mistake was a fortunate one) 3. rediscovery of
the true site of Camp Lazear on the San Jose farm of Dr. Ignacio Rojas, including
discovery of the Rojas diary with unmistakable proof, 4. Rediscovery of the now
famous “Infected Clothing Bldg.” (Bldg. #1) where Walter Reed and his colleagues
carried out one of the crucial series of experiments - the one which disproved
completely the idea held at that time, that yellow fever was caused by “infected

belongings” of yellow fever victims. This last discovery resulted after the
discovery of the Rojas day-book (Journal or diary) wherein it was stated
distinctly that “the two small wooden buildings were delivered over” to the
Rojas family and not destroyed by Walter Reed when he broke camp (as everyone,
including the Rojas family themselves - the present members - believed until
now).

Remember that Moran and Pogolotti helped me in all this (although I
started the ball rolling and kept it rolling).

The Cubans are a very sensitive (but fine) people, quick to be hurt
and quick to be pleased. And if you could mention Moran, Pogolotti, and
Madame Rojas it would please them no end and probably help me a lot with my
unfinished business in connection with the restoration of the little building
and its eventual presentation to the Cuban government. (Incidentally Mrs. Rojas
is quite a gal, a lovely, wealthy and cultured Havana lady now 80 years old.)
May I remind you also that the Cuban government (I mean that literally) are
much distressed because “Americans have consistently ignored the pioneer work
of Dr. Finlay.” As a result they have carried on a real campaign to glorify
Finlay's name (naturally at the expense of Reed et al). Therefore, we propose
to try to heal this senseless feud by using the shack (Bldg. #1) as a symbol
and means to an end, and presenting it to the Cuban government as “the place
where the concept of Finlay was proven to be correct and his great pioneering
work amplified by the experiments of the United States Army Yellow Fever Board.”

So if you can give a bit of a cheer for “dear old Finlay,” the Rochester
Post Bulletin will help old Doc Hench mighty much the next time (this spring) I
go down that-a-ways to Cuba where they play the tuba! (because I'll send 'em
a copy!)
div1.closer:
Yours for Willkie, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSE:as
P. S. I gets me an honorary Doctor of Science degree, fancy that!
